claims.claim: Intratumoral mRNA vaccination triggers local innate sensing and type I interferon signaling, creating an inflammatory state that sensitizes tumors to checkpoint blockade

evidence.quote: Type I interferon response score (normalized units) | 3.1 | 1.0
Blocking type I interferon signaling with anti-IFNAR1 eliminated the observed sensitization benefit

claims.caveat: While the interferon response and its necessity are well-supported by experimental controls, the precise molecular pathways of innate sensing in different tumor types may vary and require further characterization

claims.claim: Intratumoral mRNA vaccination significantly expands the MHC-I presented peptide repertoire, improving tumor visibility to T cells

evidence.quote: Fraction of proteins represented in MHC-I peptidome | 40.6% | 20.6%
Fraction of tumor proteins represented in immunopeptidome | 62.3% | 37.3%

claims.caveat: The expansion in antigen presentation was demonstrated across multiple models but was characterized as strongest in specific model systems rather than uniformly consistent

claims.claim: Combining intratumoral mRNA vaccination with anti-PD-L1 therapy improves tumor control in preclinical models through complementary mechanisms

evidence.quote: PD-L1 expression fold-change in tumor tissue | 2.4x | 1.0x

claims.caveat: Preclinical efficacy may not translate directly to all human tumors; mouse model effects require validation in clinical trials

claims.claim: Patients who received SARS-CoV-2 mRNA vaccination showed improved survival outcomes when undergoing immune checkpoint inhibitor treatment compared to unvaccinated patients

evidence.quote: Retrospective human survival comparison p-value | p=0.01
The vaccinated subgroup had improved survival under ICI treatment

claims.caveat: This finding is based on retrospective observational data; the analysis is non-randomized and subject to confounding factors including variable vaccination timing and heterogeneous patient characteristics

claims.claim: The proposed mechanistic chain from mRNA vaccination to improved ICI responsiveness is biologically coherent and well-supported by the cumulative evidence

evidence.quote: 1. Intratumoral mRNA vaccination triggers local innate sensing and type I interferon signaling. 2. Interferon-associated antigen processing and presentation pathways increase. 3. A broader peptide repertoire appears on MHC-I, improving tumor visibility to T cells. 4. PD-L1 pathway activity also increases, creating a rationale for combining with checkpoint blockade. 5. Combined intervention improves tumor control in mice and aligns with better outcomes in the retrospective human cohort

claims.caveat: While the overall mechanistic chain is coherent, individual steps and their relative contributions across different tumor types require further systematic investigation
